content: The target behavior in this case is for adults 45 years old or older to complete an online questionnaire on cardiovascular health. Using the concept of reward loops, we can understand this behavior as being reinforced and strengthened by the rewards and incentives that are available for completing the questionnaire. When adults 45 years old or older complete the questionnaire, they receive rewards and incentives such as information about their own cardiovascular health, access to resources and support, and the satisfaction of contributing to research and improving public health. These rewards and incentives serve as positive reinforcement for the behavior of completing the questionnaire, which increases the likelihood that the behavior will be repeated in the future. As adults 45 years old or older continue to complete the questionnaire, they are likely to develop a habit of completing it, which further reinforces and strengthens the behavior. By understanding the role of reward loops in the target behavior, the company can design an intervention that includes effective and appealing rewards and incentives to encourage the target population to complete the questionnaire.
